subject: Re: [junit] remove test from suite?
msgSnippet: ... Strange.  I have never seen that in JUnit.  Since JUnit doesn t count the # of assertions of a method, it has no possibility to know if 3, 1 or 0
messageBody:
> the problem was with the cactus sample (a servlet testing framework that
> uses junit). there was one test class that had two of its test methods not
> implemented (emtpy method body). with these being no-ops, running the tests
> failed with an error (not a failure). commenting these out let me run
> the sample.

Strange. I have never seen that in JUnit. Since JUnit doesn't count the # of assertions of a method, it has no possibility to know if 3, 1 or 0 assertions have been executed. So JUnit cannot see the difference between:
public void testDummy() {}
and
public void testDummy() { assertTrue(true); }
in term of # of evaluated assertions.

So it's maybe a Cactus feature (I don't use Cactus).

> >- find the testsuite that includes this class and remove the
> >addTestSuite(myFaultyClass.class) call
>
> unfortunately, the suite() method just returns a new TestSuite(name.class);

so define the TestSuite suite() method in the TestCase and only add the tests you want.

> >Did I mentioned that it was ugly? :-)
>
> yes, it is ugly, but an interesting approach.

I sincerely hope that _nobody_ will _ever_ consider this as something to implement! Maybe some can argue that "it's the smallest thing that can work" but it cannot be viable in the long term and the sure path to speghetti code. If you want to implement a soft-error mechanism, you need a ErrorHandler interface and/or better defined FailedAssertion (with the type of the failure) and maybe a huge refactoring.

-Vladimir
